div.l: THE CONSTANT MAID
A Comedy.
Written by James Shirley.
LONDON, Printed by I. Raworth, for R. Whitaker. 1640.

div.head: The names of the persons.
div.l: Hornet, a rich Usurer.
Hartwell, a young Gentleman, Lover of Mistresse Frances.
Playfaire, a Gallant.
A Gentleman, Cousen to Playfaire.
Sir Clement, a Justice.
Startup, a foolish Gentleman.
A Countrey-man.
Close, Servant to Hartwell.
Three Servants, disguised sometimes as Lords, one of them once disguised as a Pursevant.
A Constable.
Three Watchmen.
Masquers.
Officers.
Servants and Attendants.
Bellamy, a Widdow.
Frances, her Daughter.
Nurse, their Servant.
Neece to Hornet.
The Scene, London.

div.stage: Enter Hartwell, Close, and three other Servants.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Nay let’s not part so heavily.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: For mine owne part
It does not trouble me so much, that you
Have broke up house; for hospitalitie

Went out of fashion with crop-doublets
†crop-doublet. A short doublet. Obsolete.(OED n. C3).
doublet. A close-fitting body-garment, with or without sleeves, worn by men from the 14th to the 18th centuries. (Rarely applied to a similar garment worn by women.) Obsolete exc. Historical. (OED n. 1a).

And cod-peeces cod-peeces A (padded) pouch attached to the front of a man's close-fitting hose or breeches to cover the genitals, commonly worn in the 15th and 16th cent. (OED “codpiece”, n. 1a).: but I that have worne out
So many liveries under the worshipfull
Old Gentleman your father.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: My father had an office, which brought in
A faire revenew; I inherit but
His little land, whose annuall profits wo'not
Encourage me to live at the same height:
Yee may meet better fortunes, there's enough
Preferment in the world; my love and best
Assistance promise to your selves.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: I do not
Stand upon wages, Sir, I will not leave you.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: How woot thou live?

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: As other mortals do; yet I'll not play
The thiefe, that is a course by which a man
May soone ascend the ladder of preferment:
But I ne're lov'd these climbing trees. I cannot
Cheat, though I have heard there is an art,
A devillish deale of knowledge in the dice;
And if men wonot part with money, some
Will fetch it out o'th' bones: but the best casting
Is in a Taverne, when the wine and reckoning
Come up together; some doe spin a living by't:
And there are many secret wayes for Serving-men
To live, it is not wages does maintaine
All of our Tribe, Sir; and especially
Those that have Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: But I am a BachelourIn the 17th and 18th centuries, it was common in English-language texts to capitalise the first letter of common “important” nouns, probably as a result of the influence of continental, particularly German, books. However, this was not done systematically; one reason may be that each printer had their own personal preferences. .

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: I pray let me be one of your buttons still then,
I am not halfe worne out; you know what mould
I'm made off, I did ever honest service;
And though my fellow Vermin can forsake
Your falling house, I doe not feare the rafters;
By this hand, Sir, I'll wait upon you, though
Like great mens servants, I do live on nothing
But looks, and the aire of commendations.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: Well, since you are so resolute, attend me,
The rest I here discharge, there's somewhat more,
Not worth the name of bountie, I wish all
A happier entertainment.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: And there be
No remedy, heaven blesse you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to wet my lips with these
My fellowes, sorrow has made but a dry proverb,
I must toth' Taverne, and condole a quart.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: Meet me at Mistresse Bellamy’s then.

div.fw: The Constant Maid, Act I Scene I

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: I shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: How now Masters.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: You speake not
To me, Sir, I am a servant still indeed;
With them the case is alter'd, they are masters,
For they want services.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: Oh, Master Playfaire.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: It is not now as when Andrea liv'dAs the 1833 editor points out, some of the lines said by the servants in this passage are taken from Hieronimo’s monologue in scene V of The Spanish Tragedy, a very popular and influential play in the English Renaissance theatre written by Thomas Kyd between 1582 and 1592. ,

sp.speaker: Servant 3.
sp.l: This place was made for pleasure, not for death.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: There was a time when mortals whetted knives.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: In time of yore, when men kill'd brutish beasts.

sp.speaker: Servant 3.
sp.l: Oh cruell Butcher, whosoe're thou wert.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: Do not you know what all this signifies?

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: My master has given over house-keeping.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: He has committed Burglarie, broke up the cellar,
And throwne the kitchin out at the hall window.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: His house, Sir, has a superscription,
And is directed to his loving friend
Will pay the rent, you'l hardly know me now,
I have no fellow.

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: You are verie merrie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: He has some cause, we are discharg'd.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: For certaine, my master only
Belongs to me, if you would speake with him,
He's gone to Mistresse Bellamy’s, Sir;
In the meane time, please you to understand,
I Close follow my master, and shall feed still,
Although my fellowes here are become blanks,
And do want filling.

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: Lads, I have knowne you long:
Although you be at losse, in confidence
Of all your future honesties, I'll employ yee
In a device, which if it hit, may
Reward your paines.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: All?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Your Master only, Sir, belongs to you,
Follow him still, and if there be occasion,
I shall enquire for you; you will be faithfull.

sp.speaker: Servants Omnes
sp.l: Doubt not, Mr. Playfaire.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I have a project,
Follow me for instructions; farewell Close,
Commend me to your master.

sp.speaker: Servant 2
sp.l: Buoy Close, buoy honest Close, we are blanks, blanks.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Roule up your selves in paper-liveries, and
Be drawne at the next Lotterie; I wo'not
Forsake my certaintie for all your projects,
If it should faile I shall find some of you

Sneaking in Paul'sClose is most probably referring to the Old St Paul’s Cathedral, which was destroyed shortly afterwards in the Great Fire of London in 1666 and rebuilt as we know it today. Despite its decay at the time, the cathedral was in the 17th century one of the focal points of London’s cultural, literary and political life, as well as a popular pilgrimage site. behind a pillar, with
A zealous prayer, some Gentleman would read

The bed-roll†bed-roll. A list of persons to be specially prayed for. Obsolete or archaic.(OED “bead-roll”, n. 1). of your commendationcommendation.An office originally ending with the prayer Tibi, Domine, commendamus, in which the souls of the dead were commended to God; said both before their burial, and in anniversary or commemorative services. Liturgical (gen. In plural; also Commendation of Souls). (OED n. II. 6a). Commendatory prayer (OED n. II. 6b).,
And pitie a verie serviceable fellow,
That would faine wait on him, but wants a cloake:
Go, prosper with your project.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in Mistresse Bellamy’s House.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Widdow, be rul'd by me, I know the world,
And I have studied it these fiftie yeares:
There's no man to be trusted.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Without good.
Securitie, you meane.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: No young man, widdow,
That talks, and sayes he loves you, writes you verses,
And sweares he shall goe hang himselfe, unlesse
You pitie him; take me an old man.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: So, take you an old man.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Season'd with care and thrift, not led away
By vicious conversation, nor corrupted
With pride and surfeit, one that knowes the use
Of money; Do yee mark the use?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Yes, Sir:
Use upon use, you meane.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: And dares not spend it prodigally, knowing
The principall end it was ordain'd to, was
To releeve our necessitie, and lay up
What is above.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: To help the poore.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You may,
If you be so dispos'd, but 'tis as commendable
To give it in your will, to build an Hospitall,
And so our charitie comes altogether:
I would not have your state be eaten up
By Catterpillers, but preserv'd and made
Greater, by marrying some discreet old man.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: And such an one you show your selfe.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You happily
Interpret me.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I would not tell you, Sir,
Till our next meeting, how much you have won,
By your good counsell, on me.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She inclines.
'Tis your good nature, I am plaine, and have
No tricks, I'll tell you all my fault, I am
Addicted verie much to gather wealth;
I have no children to devoure my state,
Nor kinred, only a Neece left to my trust,
One that is never like to marrie.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She never thriv'd since she came to mee.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I easily beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Melancholly
Will kill her, and yet I pursue all wayes
That promise her delight: I spare no cost
Of Physick, what her Doctor sayes, is done.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Tis lovingly perform'd.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: A Gentleman that beares my daughter much
Affection.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Sure I have seene him.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Master Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Oh, he's a beggar, or must be verie shortly.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Have you his lands in morgage?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Not yet, not yet; but he'll want money, widdow.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: He has had good breeding.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Hang breeding, 'tis unlucky,
They never keep their state that have too much on't,
Counsell your daughter, Mistresse Bellamy,
To throw him off betime†betime.In good time, early, seasonably. Obsolete. (OED adv. 1)..

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You direct well.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: When we are married, I'll provide a match for her.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You have care on's.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: It will become me.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Is he Suitor to your mother, Lady?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: He would be such a thing: Were not I blest
In such a jolly father in law?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: He looks like some cast money-bag, that had given up
The stuffing, and for want of use growne mouldy:
He dares not keep much fire in's kitchin, lest
Warming his hands, which rather looke like gloves,
So tann'd and thin, he let em scorch, and gather
Into a heap. I do not think he ever
Put off his clothes, he would run-mad to see
His owne anatomy, that such a wretch
Should have so vast a wealth.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I wod not be his
Niece for all his fortune.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I presume
Your mother is more noble, than to encourage him
In his pretence, and her estate would mix
But ill with his ill-gotten wealth, extorted
From widdowes and from or plans, nor will all
His plentie keep his soule one day from famine:
'Tis time ill spent to mention him, let's talk
Of something else.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Of love agen,
Whose flame we equally divide.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Your table
Is a devourer, and they shut up doores
First, that keep open house and entertainments:
This Lord is feasted, and that young Ladies
Sweet tooth must have a banquet; t'other old
Madam with ne're a tooth must have some marchpanemarchpane.Historical for “marzipan”.
Corall to rub her gums withall; these are
Ridiculous expences.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Far from thrift.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: This roome has too rich furniture, and worse
Hangings would serve the turne; if I may be
Worthy to counsell, costly pictures are
Superfluous, though of this, or t'other masters
Doing: Hang Michael AngeloMichelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni (1475-1564), Italian Renaissance sculptor, painter, architect and poet. and his oyles.
If they be given, y'are the more excus'd
To let 'em shew; but have a care you let not
Appeare, either in Arras, or in picture,

The storie of the ProdigallHornet advises Bellamy not to display art depicting the Parable of the Prodigal Son, one of the parables of Jesus Christ in the Bible, appearing in Luke 15:11-32. The parable is framed as a response to a criticism of Jesus by the Pharisees and scribes for receiving sinners and eating with them, and emphasises God’s mercy towards the repentant. Hornet seems to warn that, if Bellamy shows this parable to her young male guests, they may restrict how much they spend on their dowries., 'twill fright
Young Gentlemen that come to visit you
From spending o'their portions, whose riot
May enrich you with their forfeited estates;
I have a thousand precepts more.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But do not
Think all this while of heaven.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: 'Tis in my chest,
And multiplyed in everie bag.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Or Hell.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A fable to fright fooles, or children; but
I cannot stay, my Scrivener doth expect me,
I'll visit you another time, sweet widdow,
And give you more instructions.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Spare your travell
I sha'not practise these in haste, and must
Declare these precepts make not for your welcome:
My patience was a vertue all this while,
If you but think you have a soule; repent;
Your rules I am not covetous to follow,
Good master Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Live and be undone then:
You'l tell me another tale hereafter widdow.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Letters from Master Startup, the countrey Gentleman

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: A Sutor of my Nurses commendations.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Now heaven deliver me, what have I seen?
This monster once was shewne i'th' faire, or such
Another furr'd Baboone for all the world,
Do'st know him? Why do I ask such a question?
He's such a thing the Devill would not owne's
Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Master Hornet, the great Usurer.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Hornet? Nay then, my wonder's over, and the
Devill be but such another, they
May be sworne brothers; yes, and divide hell
Betwixt em.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Who is that you talk on, Sir?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: The beast, that Heaven be thank'd, has left you,
Hornet; but I ha newes for you.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I'll heare it in the garden.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Do you love
That Master Hartwell? do not blush, but answer.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I hope you move†move.Transitive. To propose or suggest (something to be done); to prefer (a request); to lodge (a complaint); to bring forward, propound (a question, etc.), mention (a matter). Also with to (a person). Obsolete. (OED v. 30a). not this, as if you doubted;
I took him first, upon your character,
Into my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But things alter:
What then I thought, I deliver'd yee;
Nor since hath he deserv'd a lesse esteeme
In his owne person, but the circumstance
Is not the same, his fortune I have examin'd,
Which rises not to such a value, I
Did apprehend; and it becomes my care,
Being at one gift to depart with thee
And my estate, to look for one whose purse
May carrie a proportion.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Make me not
Imagine you would wed me to a heap
Of shining dust, a golden bondage.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Nor
To penurie; his birth, and education
Are not unworthy, he's a handsome man too;
But be not govern'd by your eye too much:
Children and age pursue, and many stormes
Hover about our fraile conditions:
All these must be provided for, they are not
Kisses will arme you against winter, therefore
Confident of your obedience, I propound
Another to your best thoughts,

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Oh my unhappinesse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: A Countrey Gentleman of spreading fortunes,
Young too, and not uncomely; for his breeding,
It was not spun the finest, but his wealth,
Able to guild deformitie, and make
Even want of wit a vertue, when your life
Renders it selfe more sweet by your command;
His name is Master Startup, whom I expect
Our guest to morrow, that's his letter, read it.
This may seeme strange at the first coming toward you;
But when discretion comes to examine what
A fruitfull consequence attends it, you
Will thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: But with your pardon, mother,
Although I could dispence with my owne thoughts,
And frame them to obedience, will this change
Be for my honour, or my fame? when such
A noble Gentleman shall boast he had,
With your consent, my love? or pray admit
That which we gaine by riches of the second,
Seeme to authorize, and may justifie
The act with some; how can it cure the wound,
Which the poore heart, which loves, shall find too soone,
When 'tis neglected, and so cruelly,
Where it did hope for cherishing? Oh think
How you did love my father first, and be
More gentle to your daughter, your estate
Is above needy providence, or grafting
Into a new stock; it doth grow already
Faire from his owne root, and doth want no peecing:
Nor are the meanes of Hartwell so contemptible.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: No more: y'have consider'd well, you'l shape
Another answer; i'th' meane time dispose
Your countenance to entertaine this new
And able Lover: leave the satisfaction
Of Hartwell to my care:
He's here, to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I know not what's the trick on't, nor themselves yet;
But he has a project to employ 'em all.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I wish it well; but do you work your selfe
Into the opinion of her Nurse, she is
The Major Domo, and has all the intelligence.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Let me alone, I'll work her Sir like wax,
To print what forme you please upon her, 'tis
A Loving Crone already to me, I
Will speake her faire, and in my drink may marrie her.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Master Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: About your businesse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: There is a matter, Sir, which I must open,
And you perhaps will wonder at.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You prepare my attention.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You do love my daughter,
At least I think so.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If you knew my heart,
You might be confident, in her I sum
All my desires on earth.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Be not so fixt.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: How Lady?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: When you have heard me out, you'l find
Your consent easie to call back a promise
Made to your disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I acknowledge;
This makes me wonder, pray interpret Lady,
And speake the dialect I understand:
I love your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But must never glorie
In the reward which you expect should be,
Her marriage.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: In the number of my actions
There is not one that's guiltie of so much
Offence to you, that I should be so soone
Lost to your favour.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Have no thought so poore
You can deserve lesse, my opinion
Is richer laden with your merit.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Now I feare agen, this violent turne of praise
Makes me suspect my state; if I be falne,
Teach me to know my trespasse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I ne're look'd
With such cleere eyes into your worth, and 'twere
A sin to generall goodnesse, to delay
The free resigne of that your worth may challenge.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If this be meant, pray pardon my mistake
Of something went before, love made me feare;
You said I never should enjoy your daughter
In marriage, which your selfe so late enclined to.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: And must agen repeat, you cannot call
Her Bride.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Can you forbid this happinesse,
And love me?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Yes, so deerly, Hartwell, I
Present my selfe to thy affection.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You fright my understanding.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Does the name
Of widdow sound displeasing, I have learn'd
Already to obey; my yeares are not
So many, with the thought, to freeze your bloud,
I weare no print of time deep in my brow:
Have my haires the innocence of age,
To speake me twice a child? Gentlemen active,
And of great birth, have courted my affection
And if they flatter not, commend my person.
Adde unto this my wealth, no narrow fortune,
And without competition, my daughter,
Depending on my love, whose portion must
Flow from my bountie, or be nothing; make
A sober apprehension of this tender,
And think I was not able to suppresse
My silent flame, increast still by your vertues:
This minute give all hopes up for my daughter,
I can admit no Rivall; 'tis within
Your election to be happie, Sir:
My love accepted comes with faire attendance,
Deny'd, you hasten your owne exile, think on't,
I will expect your answer.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I am destroy'd:
Was it her mother that spake all this while?
As pilgrims, by mistake of some small path,
Having told many wearie steps, at night,
When their hopes flatter em, they are not far
From some kind entertainment, find themselves
Lost in a wildernesse; so am I miserable:
Thus love delights to wound, and see us bleed,
He were a gentle god to kill indeed.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Fye, fie, I am asham'd of you, a Gentleman
Of your high promising, and be put off
So slightly?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Why Nurse, what would you ha' me do?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Do? I would have you do something; a man
Of your ability, and cannot turne
And winde a woman?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: You wo'd not ha' wish'd me
To ha' put her to't behinde the hangings?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You should ha' been round with her.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I was round with her, I call'd her asse and coxcombe,
And twenty more names, unlesse I should
Ha' call'd her whore, I could not be more round with her.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I do not mean that way.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: And she call'd me,
I thank her.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Why no worse than her sins, heaven forgive her,
She has the more to answer; nay she did
Not stick to bid me die too, in that desparate
Estate.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Come, you shall take another course.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: What ayles my Masters sweet-heart, she frighted?
I met and askt her for my Master, and
She turn'd tayle lik a hound had lost the scent;
There's something in the winde, my three pil'd worship
Are you there with my Lady o'th' Larder,
Now in that posture? do not they two look like
A fine Brick house and a thatched Barne in the Countrey,
Laying their heads together? they ha' spied me.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Come hither Close, nay he's faithfull, and one that
Has a desire to serve you; you may trust him.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Your worship may trust me a bed with— I
Have had a itch this great while, sir, a kinde
Of longing to be one of your appurtenances:
I have some faults, and I'll confesse 'em; I have
A humour now and then, when I am ask'd
A question, to tell true, though I be chid for't;
And I do not love blowes; you may sooner beat
My braines out, than a word of flattery:
I cannot batten upon commendation,
Without my wages, nor be valiant
Upon small Beere; I am not overmuch
Given to be drunke, but I've a tricke o'th Dutchman,
To do your businesse as well drunke as sober:
I have not impudence enough to pimpe
For you, but I have a gift I can say nothing:
I was borne upon Shrovetuesday, and shall be
Now and then given to rebellion:
My flesh will once a year rise at a Chamber-maid;
If none such take me downe, I shall in malice
And deep revenge, fling out upon May-day,
Among the Prentices, without fear or wit.
And she may be compell'd to marry him in
Her owne defence; there have been such devises.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Does he consent?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: She is betraid to't, sir.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Then thou wo't be so base?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: And I had meant it,
I never had told you this: can you make use
Of this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Thou art my honest servant.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I promis'd to be his.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I have it; Canst
By any meanes procure me but his clothes?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: With ease, he'll go to bed betimes, to avoid
Suspicion; that's a part of our designe.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I could not wish a happy opportunity,
To try how she affects this gaudy foole,
And clear my faith to her, which her mothers watch
Will not permit; she has, I feare, perceiv'd
My new familiarity with her mother,
Which I am compell'd too, and must cleer this way:
Faile me not, Close, and propound thy owne
Reward.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Tell me your purpose, and let my wit
Dispose of him.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Prosper me love in this.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: And you fall to prayers
With good love, look about us, I shall suspect
You wo'not thrive; you should go to a wench,
As Gentlemen to Oysters, without ceremony
Or saying grace; devotion will spoile all.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in Justice Clement's House. A banquet set out.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Right as an Arrow Couze.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Witty enginere;
But was she taken with the plot?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I was compell'd to frame the outside of a reason,
Lest our owne mirth should play the Traytor with us,
Her spleene was so dilated, he beleeved
I have made her mad, which change makes for us.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: And he that we employed, the Pursevant,
Shewed such a fierie Raskall, the poore Usurer
Trembled, as Bawds beneath the lash.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: He comes then?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: With as much joy, as to receive a hanging:
He would be whipt, and say his prayers i'th' Church
In a white sheet.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: That were no pennance to him.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Nay, he would pay as much as he should fine
For Alderman, though halfe his soule went with it,
For his quietnesse; he doth apprehend
Nothing but earth-quakes.

div.stage: Enter three servants, disguised as Lords.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: How am I rampant
With the imagination? bid the musick
Be ready, they know all their flourishes;
But shift you quickly for your other part,
My honourable Lords;
How they doe look like States-man, where's your tooth-pick?
Excellent; beare your staffe handsomely, contract
The brow, and look more superciliously.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: I warrant you for my part.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: We came now
From practise.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Can ye do't with confidence?

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: These verie clothes have made me proud already,
It was some Lords cast sute, I'll lay my life.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: And mine, it smels of honour.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: So, so, how now man?

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: He looks pale: My Lord, how d'ee?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Well, well, I hope 'tis but conceit.

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Will the pox lie in clothes? I can not tell,
I finde some alteration in my body,
Since I shifted.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: 'Tis a meere conceit,
They were an honest mans, upon my knowledge,
A Captaine of the traine Band in the Countrey,
They were brought against the generall Master last;
He wore 'em that day, and to Church the Sunday
Following, and most carefully sent 'em up,
To taste our London Lavender.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Sir, you have satisfied me.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Be sprightly; where's this Prince?
See and attend him in fit state.

div.stage: Re-enter Cousen disguised as the King, and three servants as Lords, Sir Clement.
Cousen sits himself at the head of the board.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: He's here.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Now by that sprig, a pretty Majesty;
But wo't thou not be out of thy Kings part?
And when the Wine is wanting at the Banquet,
Call upon drawers, quarrell with your Nobles,
Or when we shall present our man of morgages,
Take him aside, and borrow halfe a crowne,
To give your whore benevolence, which trusted,
For you last tilting, or be drunke too soone,
And leave our project in the dirt.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My Lords,
This fellowes insolence must be corrected;
Dispose him in what prison you think fit.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: He's mad, I thinke.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: To Bedlam with him then,
Is this a place for fools or madmen, who
Admitted him? take him, see you
He be well whipt, and let him thanke our mercy,
Bandog.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I quake already, excellent Warbeck,
Coole, coole thy lungs, and whisper with some Lord,
Thou wo't be a key too high else, good Sir Clement,
Master of the house, at whose cost we are entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: My part is rotten
In my head, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Is he come?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: He waits in the first chamber.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Let the Lutes
Begin, and their best voice, and then admit him.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Here's revelling, my purse must be squeez'd for't:
That's the King, the rest are bare; how supple they are
I'th hams, that Courtier has Oyl'd his joynts,
He looks this way, they point at me; a rot
O'that knave’s finger.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: What fellow's this? who waits?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: It was his graces pleasure, he was sent for,
My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Mr. Hornet?
Let me have the honour to present him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is this the man whom all so much commend
For his ability.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I smell no good from that word, ability.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Discreet and read i'th' Common-wealth, a man
Fit for employment in the State.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: His countenance is promising.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: If the King of Spaine
Had but his head, that politick head,
I know who might go fish for the Low-Countreyes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: His garments are but course.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: His minde is rich.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: They praise me, I am a thousand pound the worse for’t.

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: Wilt please your Majesty?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Kneel downe; Thy name?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Giles Hornet, your poore creature.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Rise up, Sir Giles Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: But am I Knighted?

sp.speaker: Lords
sp.l: We congratulate your honour.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What must I pay for it?
I'll sell it any friend of yours againe,
For halfe the money.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Some have care to give
His body more becomming ornaments;
He shall be like himselfe, and then we will confer
More honors on him.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Do you make haste, his Grace
Will have you new thatch'd; you must have clothes
Fitting your State and honorable title.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: These will be good enough for me, 'las I am not able.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Nay, you must have 'em from his Wardrobe, sir,
They'll cost you nothing; You'll not looke in those,
Like a poore Knight of Windsor.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: When he is ready, give us knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Yes, sir.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Hornet and Lord 1.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: You were best prepare,
Your cloathes will be here presently, the King
Will send for you before you be ready; Cast
Your old skin off: Do you not to save sheets
And trouble, wrap your selves a nights i'th blankets?
Or are they ashamed to show the Linings?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Hum? if this be but preparative to a whipping,
What case am I in?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Well said, now they are come;
Be nimble now, and helpe to fit Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Alas, must I weare this doublet? it would yield
Heaven knowes how much to burne.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: You may be desparate
When 'tis on, and burne your body with it, sir,

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I sha'not know my selfe.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Be that time we ha' done wi'ye.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Fit as they were made, sir.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Which is Sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I am the man you please to call Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Then I congratulate your happy fortune;
Y'are like to be exalted, his Grace talkes
Much on you, I'll be proud to be your servant:
My Lord, a word.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The Bridegroom, Sir, in great favour, I can tell you,
And new created by his Highnesse, Baron
Of Landskip; his living is far off.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: My very good Lord, my breeches are almost on.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There be the Keyes.
sp.stage: Takes the keys from Hornet’s pocket, and gives them aside to Lord 1.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: His Grace has pleas'd to shine upon
A piece of barren earth.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: You are too modest;
The King has been informed, Sir Giles, you are
One of the ablest men in his Dominion:
Should vertue still be cloath'd in rags? Advance it
To honour, and regard you waste your braine
At home, in cheap and low engagements, sweat
Your soule out, for a poore and paltry living;
Old houses, let 'em fall to the dull Lord
O'th' Manner; switch me up a Towne together,
Or meddle not; This or that sttragling Acre's
Not worth your care; Study some Monopoly,
May sweep the Kingdome at a stake; Despise
A project wo'not bring in halfe the City;
Finde out a way to forfeit all the Charters;
Have an Exchequer of your owne, and keep
The Princes round about in pension:
These are becomming businesses, and speake
An active State-man.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You do talk strange things,
My Lord.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: His keyes are things verie
Materiall to our businesse.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: And I have 'em.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: So, so:
I will account it one of my felicities,
To be a witnesse of your Honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Oh, my good Lord of Landskip.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: How shall we dispose these?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: The Hang-man will not have them, and I feare,
They will corrupt a well; 'faith give them stable roome.

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: My Lord, the King asks for you; Good Sir Giles
Write me i'th' number of your faithfull friends.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: We must attend.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Do not yet say he's ready,
The Barber has a dutie to dispatch,
He will be houres a rubbing, washing, powdering.
Then I'll attend him to his Presence.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: We shall excuse him so long, still your servant.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: The Barber, sir, attends in the next roome.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I wo'not shave.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: He feares his throat.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I never give above three-pence.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Talk not you of charge,
You have but yet your welcome: do not you
Think, good sir Giles, but we can shave you too.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The Street near Mistresse Bellamy's House
Enter Close and Startup in his shirt.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Where is he, Close?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I told him, sir,
You lay in a chamber o'th t'other side,
The house, whither he is gone with his sword drawne,
And curses of themselves able to kill you:
You did affront him once, and now his Mistresse
Has quite neglected him, for your love, he thinks:
He'll make you an example to all Rivals;
I'll bring your clothes hereafter, yet your feare
And running, sir, will keep you warme enough.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Honest Close, thou hast sav'd my life.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Death, is he not behind you? this way, good sir.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: A Room in Mistresse Bellamy's House.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Ha’ you not made a fine choyce, I did ever
Think he was false; your mother did but counterfeit
The love-sick widdow all this while, to trie him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Trie him, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: She told me so her selfe,
Assuring him the state was hers, and you
At her devotion; put him to his choyce,
To take her with the wealth, or you with nothing:
What followed, you have heard, come be wise yet,
And love the Countrey Gentleman that dotes on you;
He's rich, and halfe a foole, I'll fetch him to you.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: My mother counterfeit? why may not Hartwell
Pretend as well as she, fearing her anger
And policie, if he refus'd her love?
I have observ'd some sorrow in his gestures,
As he were willing to deliver something,
If opportunitie would give him leave;
He cannot be so false, now I suspect
He does obey some dire necessitie:
'Twould puzzle a wise lover to be so
Severely put to't.

div.stage: Nurse brings in Hartwell in Startups clothes.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: On like a bold Captaine,
Give her a broad side, she's within your shot,
I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: 'Tis the foole, Why Nurse?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Nay, fly not before you heare.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: 'Tis Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If my voyce
Betray me not.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Why in this shape? some trick in't,
He hides his face, I'll put him to't however,
Although the houre be unseasonable, any time
We may expresse our joy: my Nurse once told me
You were not well, and gone to bed, your health
Is welcome as my owne; I dare not, sir,
In modestie presume to bid you stay,
And to requite your paines, kind Mr. Startup.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: She knowes me not.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Forgive me if I blush,
I have no other way, but to declare
My eyes that late frown'd on your love shall smile.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: On me?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: On none but you: I have beene too
Unkindly dealt withall by Hartwell, whom
How dearly I affected, good Heaven knowes:
But I have read discretion to my fancie,
And were he here, he should be witnesse of
My vowes to you, if you accept my heart,
And can with equall truth embrace it, I
Will chuse my husband here; you, only you,
This faith be registred in Heaven, shall challenge from me a wives obedience.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Planet-struck.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Away, your mother's up; I wo'd not for
A thousand pound she find you in this chamber.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I have undone my selfe.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Startup, to your owne lodging,
Take that close lanthorne with you:
Passion of me, what makes her rise?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I will discover yet.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Discover; what?
Ha, Mr. Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You ha' midnight plots.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Oh, we are wretched, miserable, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Oh, who shall lead me to a world where are
No women? Farewell all, I'll be above
Your charms, and find out death, a cure for love.

div.stage: Enter Startup, wrapped in a blanket, followed by Close.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Where are we now? 'tis verie cold, why do'st not
Lead me to some house?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: What, at this time a night?
All people are a bed, the verie Owles
Are in their dead sleep; or if we could
Be admitted, would you venture a this fashion,
And publish your disgrace, proclaime your selfe
Coward, and lay some imputation
Upon the place you came from, where your hopes
May yet be faire for marriage? This brunt over.
To meet some Drunkard now were comfortable,
Whose eyes enflamed might serve for torches,
Or he might spit flapdragons from his fire
Of Sack, and light us: But no sober man,
Considering what case you are in, sir,
By my consent should see you.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Ha, what's that?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Where, where? a fire-drake.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Now 'tis gone: 'tis bright
Agen, Is't not a spirit? Oh deliver me.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I have heard some such things use to walke the fields.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Pray, pray with as much strength
As if you had no land, or were confined
To my annuity: Now I feare no spirits;
This riches makes us cowards; Hide your selfe,
I will go neerer.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Dost know the devill if thou seest him, Close?
A pox of love, if this be the reward on't;
Some call it fire, but I finde no such matter;
I am frozen to the Blanket, and my teeth
Strike one another, and keep time like hammers
That beat a Psalme upon the vertuous Anvile;
I do beleeve if they were beaten out,
They would make false Dyce, there's quicksilver in 'em,
I know already by their dancing.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Sir, where are you?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Here I am still.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Y'are a dead man.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: More terrour? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: 'Tis my Master with a darke.
Lanthorne, that pursues us: By
This darknesse, 'tis his voice, wrap your selfe up,
And roule into some ditch, flight will betray us.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I had as good be kill'd, but yet I'll venture.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed, and more than I expected:
The matters do not fadge well with his Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What a sweet thing is night? how calme and harmlesse?
No whispering, but of leaves, on which the breath
Of heaven playes Music to the birds that slumber;
Here are no objects to betray our sence
To repentance, nor can women, thus
Advantag'd by the Tapers of the night,
Spread their temptations to undoe poore man:
What a fine book is heaves? which we may read
Best now, when every Star is a faire letter:
How much they wrong thee night, which call thee guilty
Of rapes and murders: 'Tis the day, that like
A glorious whore, engages men to act 'em,
And taking then the darknesse to obscure 'em:
We unjustly lay the shame upon thy browes,
That art so innocent; Thou never sawest them
Befriended with this silence; I begin
To wander: There's no wildernesse abroad,
To him that's lost at home.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: One that has taken paines for you to night:
I am Close.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What mak'st thou here?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I wait upon
My charge; I led your Rivall a procession
In's shirt, perswading him you had resolv'd
To cut his throat else; he's hard by at's prayers,
And thinkes you ha' pursued him.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Ha, I'll do't;
Show me the foole, by all my hopes I'll kill him,
And send his base heart as a present to her:
Fate has preserved me with this revenge,
And I will not delay his death a minute.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: You wo'not kill him basely?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Why not?
There is no feare but he'll live long enough;
I'll undertake he never shall go provided
To fight w'ee; and for other satisfaction,
Name it, and take it; so I'll fetch him to ye.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Stay, I have been too passionate, let him live
To be her punishment; that's revenge enough,
While I pursue my owne wayes.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Whither now?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Whither thou must not follow, by thy honesty,
I charge thee come not after me.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: That bindes my attendance, sir.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: But not when I command
The contrary, if thou dost move this way,
Thou drawest my anger; Minde the preservation
Of the tame thing you undertooke; Farewell,
If thou dost love me, follow not, nor question
'Tis in my power to loose thee or my selfe.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I cannot see i'th'darke with spectacles,
And mine owne eyes ha' lost him o'the suddaine;
Well, I must hope the best; What shall I do
With my hen-hearted lover, that would give
Halfe his estate his colde fit were well over:
I shall make worke for the Physicians :
Candles and Cullices will never restore him;
If he but scape with life, I am not sorry,
He may be a souldier, and indure the trenches;
I put him first to the becomming sufferance:
But what are these? an army of hornes and Halberds?
Upon my conscience, the Watch; I thought
The fields had not been haunted with these goblins:
I cannot run; If I should squat, and they finde me,
There were no mercy but Bride-well,
Or some such lovely place; I am resolv'd
To cast away a few good words upon 'em,
A leg and worshipping; the Constable
That leads the rusty Regiment will quit me,
I passe the gates wo't often, and so may
The devill if he pay the Porter; blesse you:
My masters what a clocke is't?

sp.speaker: Watchman 1
sp.l: Who's theere?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: I charge you stand.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Your worship may do much.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Where have you beene?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: At Islington, and please you, about businesse.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Some thiefe, I warrant him, no honest man,

div.l: I know by his basket hilt, some rogue that watches,
The fields are pester'd with such sturdy robbers.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: He is a rogue that watches, for my part.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: He cals my watchmen rogues.

sp.speaker: Watchman 1
sp.l: How Mr. Constable? you are one your selfe.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: A way with him.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Watchman 2
sp.l: We will provide you a lodging.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: New Prison.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: But are you in earnest, Gentlemen?
If there be no remedy.

sp.speaker: Watchman 2
sp.l: We'll humble you.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I have a companion hereabouts: where are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Here in the ditch.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: They seldome go alone:
We'll finde him out; ha sirra.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I thanke you honest men: where art thou Close?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Here; these good men will helpe us to a lodging.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Blessing on their hearts, I am almost starv'd.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Yes, we'll do you that favour; Come away, sir.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Whether shall we go now?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: To prison.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: How, Close?

sp.speaker: Watchman 1
sp.l: You shal be close enough.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: D'ee heare, sweet Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I follow, Sir, I cannot leave you in adversity;
All this is for your health, cleane straw is warme, sir;
You have the benefit of being naked:
I shall have worke to morrow in the woollen.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Away, away; bring them away

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in mistresse Bellamy's Home.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I heard some noise; looke, call up the servants,
See if the Gentleman be a bed; I'm troubled.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Oh Mistrisse?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Mr. Startup is not a bed, and here is all is left
Of Mr. Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: This is verie strange.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I dare not tell her of his shift, they're gone,
The doores I found left open, and no signe
Which way they are bestowed.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: This puzzles me:
Pray Heaven there be no mischiefe in this absence:
Is Franck abed?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: What should move'em
To leave my house so late, and Mr. Hartwell
Without his clothes? Some knock there:
Beshrew me but I trembled.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: 'Tis a stranger,
And sayes he would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: At this late houre?
What accidents are these? from whence?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Has he no name? what should this meane?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: He sayes he is a Countrey-man of Mr. Startups.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Admit him, he perhaps does bring some newes.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: By your leave Mistresse, pardon my importunitie
At so unfit an houre.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Y'are welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Country-man
sp.l: I met with fortunate directions,
Though I came late; I understand you have
A guest, one Startup of Northampton-shire,
That comes a wooing to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Such an one there was that supt with us, and went
To bed; but since, as I have faith, I know not
Which way he has convey'd himselfe; another
Gentleman too is missing, and his Rivall.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: Pray do not mock me, Lady, I ha rid
A great way, and the businesse much concernes him.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You may beleeve me, he is no such treasure
I should conceale him.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: Then I see you dally:
Know, Mistresse, you may slack your preparations,
Your daughter must look out another husband,
He is contracted.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: And something more,
Gotten with child one, that without blushing
I cannot call my daughter; he shall make
Her credit straight agen, although my fortunes
Have no equalitie with his, I shall
Find Law to force him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: You preferr'd this sutor,
This newes returnes my bloud.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Sir, you shall find
All truth I have deliver'd, I am not sorrie,
To heare this newes, this is no time to seek him:
Please you accept the lodging that was his,
My servant shall attend you in the morning,
To help your search.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: You seeme a noble Gentlewoman,
I take your courtesie.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Nurse, a light; pray walk, sir.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I was unkind to Hartwell, he not wise;
But love still apprehends too much, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Frances, a word: do not you know what is
Become o' these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Not I, their absence
Is strange to me.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Oh, Franck, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Good Heaven, forbid.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: This Gentleman, Mr. Hartwell,
Whom we shall never see agen, I feare.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: How, mother? are you acquainted
With any cause to feare thus.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Tis in vaine
To tell thee how I loved him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Blesse my senses! you love him?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Bove all the world, affectionately plac'd him
Too neere my heart.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I heard you made pretence
Of Love, to trie him for my sake; and pardon me,
If yet I dare not beleeve more.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Oh Franck—

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: My heart doth thrill, I feele a coldnesse run
Through all my veines already.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I had no other thought,
At first; but wisely to distinguish whether
His heart was fixt on thee, or my estate;
With resolution, if I found him more
A Courtier of thy fortune than thy person,
To punish him with losse of both: But Love
Hath chang'd both scene and title in our Comedy,
And what I meant should shipwrack all his hopes,
Hath ruin'd us, his modest and calme answer:
To accept my tender, with such force and reason
Directed to my fancie, turn'd my purpose,
And made me his indeed, his perfect Lover:
But now we ha' both lost him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: All the pietie
That ever taught children to love their mother,
Will but suffice to keep my heart obedient.
Was ever Maid so miserable? Was there
No other, in my fate, to rivall me
I live too long; oh breake, breake my poore heart;
For she that gave me life, hath took it from me.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I do not weep, or if
I do, I know not why.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Now I perceive
Thy duty was but counterfeit, you love him,
Upon my life you love him still; Have my
Commands no more respect? My care and love
So ill rewarded, that my heart desiring
One comfort in the world, and shall my childe
Rise up to take it from me?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Alas I knew not
You loved him too, indeed I had rather die
Than you should call me rebell.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Now I see
The cause of his departure in this fashion,
Pray heaven he have not made away himselfe:
Did ever childe deceive a mother so?
I have a sad presage, you may to bed,
And rise without my blessing, yet
You may stay, wherefore should I despaire
Of his returne? You say you could not tell
That I affected him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Indeed not I,
And do believe it now against my will;
But I am your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Show it, in confirming
Your selfe to my desires, and what is past,
I can forgive you, if he come againe:
Will you be rul'd, and show no favour to him?
For 'tis in you, I see, to make me happy;
I will not tie you to affect the other,
Choose any for your husband but this man,
My love and prayers shall go along with you;
Answer.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Indeed I dare not, yet could I
Put off the knowledge that you are a mother—

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Though in imagination I allow you
The greatest woman in the earth, whose frowne
Could kill, and eyes at pleasure make alive
Agen; I could say—

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Pray let's heare.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I durst tell you,
In confidence of my cause, that you betray
Two innocents to sorrow; and though heaven
Looke on, and seem to smile upon your cruelty,
Yet there is punishment for divorcing those
Whose hearts that hath conjoyned: I durst tell you,
Though all your terrours were prepared to punish
My bold defence; you were a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: A most unjust, a sacrilegious tyrant.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You would not be so violent.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: That thus,
Not only ruine and deface the Altar,
But steal away the very Sacrifice,
And I durst adde and smile upon your anger.
Though as you frown'd death stood in every wrinckle,
My soul's above your tyranny, and would
From torturing flame, receive new fire of love,
And make your eye faint to behold the brightnesse
Of my poore bodies Martyrdome; and if ever
Love shewed a miracle, my heart should beare
The Characters of him you have torne from it,
With beames about it like a Saint that suffer'd:
But as you are my mother, thus I kneele
And beg a pardon for my innocence,
If that offend you; Live you happy still,
And be the Mistris of your vowes, live to
Enjoy whom you affect, may every houre
Returne new blessings on you both; renew
Your spring, and let him thinke you young againe,
And let me beg but this for all my duty;
Against that day you marry him to provide
My Coffin, for I feare I shall, not have
Breath many minutes after, to pray for you.
The herbs that shall adorne your Bridall chamber,
Will serve my Funerall, and deck my Merse;
Beneath which you should say, there lies your daughter
That dies to shew obedience.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Why shouldst thou
Continue thus to him?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I know he loves me, yet hereafter your affections
May not.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But never procure thee one sad thought;
Now I have tried you both; assure my childe,
I loved him but for thee, dispose thy selfe
To be his Bride: This newes, at his returne,
Will make all well to rest.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Twere sin to mocke thee any more: To bed.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I'll spend all night
In prayers for you, mother: Oh my Hartwell

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: A Room in Justice Clement's House.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I am bound ever to thee.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Does she not become her rich cloathes too?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: The morning never look'd
So fresh, nor Venus with more charmes upon her:
Adon would melt before her eye, and wooe her
Her kisses, at expence of his last breath:
Cupid himselfe, could he but see, would fall
In love with her, and throwing away his shafts,
Offer the empty quiver to her eyes,
Ambitious to fill it with her beames;
The least of which, would wound more hearts, than all
His stocke of golden Arrowes.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: No more Raptures.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Didst thou not know before, that love is able,
Without the helpe of Sacke, to make a Poet,
My nimble Mercury, Joves Herald in
Reversion?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I must confesse
I had a trick of Mercury when I pick'd
His pocket for the Keyes.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: He never mist 'em?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: His eyes were drench'd in fuds, and I return'd em
Ere they recover'd light.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: 'Twas excellent;
He walkes in darknesse still.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: D'ee think he'll know her?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: His cloathes already have
Made him forget himselfe, or if he have
But the remembrance of such a woman;
The more he sees her now, the more he'l thinke
The change impossible.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Where ha' you left him?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I'th' Gallery, where with much patience,
He does expect his highnesse will send for him.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Then all runs smoothe, his wonder still continues.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I fed that humour artificially;
He is halfe perswaded all's but a dream,
To which imagination his clothes
Are a great help, because he paid not for 'em:
Sometimes he is very merry, then agen
He struts about with such a scurvy pride,
As some new crept into Nobility;
When men of their first Livery come to see 'em;
His honour has so chang'him, that he now
Knowes not of what Religion he is;
Or if he chance to thinke of his first faith,
He spits o'th hangings, and excused with,
I do not like the Story, 'tis apocryphall:
Sometimes he'll offer at a jest, and talke
Non-sense with him that has been seaven yeares Lorded;
Frowne upon any man that will presume
To have more knowledge, in worse clothes; I told him
It was his Graces pleasure he should be
Controuler of the Masque, and he did sweat,
As he were studying for some mighty oathes
To cleere the presence: he is here; away.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: And you are Master of the house, Sir Clement,
For so I heard you call'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: It is my name,
Sir Giles, unworthy of this grace his Highnesse
Is daign'd to shew in honouring of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: And was she married this morning, say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: This morne she lost her Virgin name.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I have not seen her yet, nor any of the Ladies,
You have but little noise methinkes in the house.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: It would offend his Grace.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Who, as you say, came hither privately, with a small traine
Of Lords; Would I might see his face agen;
I am not sent for yet, I have beene ready,
Sir Clement, these three houres, and I do wonder
His Grace forgets himselfe so much.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: That Musick speaks him on entrance.

div.stage: Re-enter Cousen and three Servants, disguised as King and Lords.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I, that garbe becomes him;
How was his person lost within that shape
He was first presented to me?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Indeed the case is somewhat a
Altered, by your highnesse bounty
To your poore subject, Hornet.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Now he lookes
As he did scorne the quorum, and were hungry
To eat a Statesman; 'Las an office in
The houshold is too little for a breakfast:
A Baron, but a mornings draught, he'll gulpe it,
Like a round Egge in Muscadine: Me thinkes
At every wiping of his mouth, should drop
A golden saying of Pythagoras;
A piece of Machiavelli; I see already
Hang on his Beard (which wants but stroaking out)
The Statutes and the Magna Charta have
Taken a lease at his tongues end.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I will think on't;
He shall be — but toth' banquet,
Then let the masque be ready, there we shall
Employ your worthy diligence.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Heaven blesse your mightie Grace.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: You'll follow.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I attend you presently:
I know not what to think of these things yet,
'Tis verie strange I should be thus exalted
Without desert; best knowne unto my self.
Princes I see are mortall, and may be
Deceiv'd in placing of their honours, I
Am little better than a favorite,
If this be true: If? 'tis a question,
Let me consider wisely, it may be
I am not I. No, no, I am a Knight:
Are these my clothes? I did not use to weare such
A pocket in my sleeve and velvet hose,
Six times translated since they were a Mid-wives
Fore-part, were things I wore on holidayes.
The price of these would break a Cammels back,
And yet some men walk under 'em like Elephants,
And have varietie, as the Devill were
Their Taylour, who best knowes where all their land lies.
Then why this cost on me? it is a dreame,
And I am verie glad on't, 'tis impossible
I should be true, it does not hang together,
I will have patience till i wake agen,
And care not what becomes on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: 'Tis his Highnesse
Pleasure now the banquet's done.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: How, the banquet done? I was comming to't,
You could hardly say grace by this time.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: That's a ceremony growne out of use;
It was a running banquet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A running? so it seemes, it made great haste:
I doe dreame certainly, there's no sense nor reason
In any thing they say.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: You know your place,
The masque will straight begin, and his Grace wo'not
Have any one admitted, he resolves,
If the conceit affect him, it shall be
Perform'd i'th' Court hereafter, i'th' meane time
He does command all privacie: There are
Some set to guard the door; but your care must
Provide his Highnesse be not interrupted.
Back, they are rude already.

div.stage: Sir. Clement Exits — Knocking from within.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Let me alone:
What turbulent Knave is that?

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: I am a Countrey Gentlemen, Sir Giles;
And if I may presume upon good cloathes,
You may before his Grace call me your Cousen,
And not be asham'd; here is a Lady too.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A Lady too? Is she with child? What makes she
Here, and she be with child already?
'Tell thee none such shall be admitted, while
I am in place: More rapping? Keep the doores,
If I do fall a swearing once, look to't.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: I beseech you, for my wives sake.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Thy wives?
What's he that pleads In forma pauperis?

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: A Citizen, and like you.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Like me? thou liest: I am more like a Lord.
Thou shalt fare ne're the better for that word:
Knock downe the women, and there be a hundred.
And make their husbands drunk; the Guard are lazie:
These womens insolence will force a Statute,
I will petition to the King my self,
They may have libertie but once a yeere
To see the Gally foist, then be confined
To their Chamber, and one Prentice—yet agen.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: Sir Giles, Sir. Giles, you know me well enough.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: But while I am in office I'll know no body.

sp.speaker: Scrivenor
sp.l: I am your Scrivenor.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Draw thy purse, wherein
Thou keep'st thy eares, and leave 'em at the doore;
The Guard trust none without a pawne; they'll serve,
If they be ne're redeem'd, to seethe in milke
For a sore throat: Jewes eares I know they are.

sp.speaker: Scrivenor
sp.l: Sir Giles, here's your Neece.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: My Neece? the devill she is.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Pray Uncle let me in.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Her very voice: Ha? open the doores there;
Where is she?

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: My Neece that call'd to me.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: None call'd: nor was there any woman here.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: No, nor my Scrivener bawling out, Sir Giles,
Not at any hand your worship.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Then I dreame,
And I am a fool to make a question on't.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: The knaves laugh at me, but let 'em, I
Shall be as merry with this tale to morrow:
What fancies men have in their sleep sometimes?
His Highnesse.
sp.stage: Re-enter Sir. Clement, Cousen and Servants, disguised as before; Cousen takes his seat.
sp.l: Where be the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: They are all i'th' Masque.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Nay, 'tis no matter, why do I aske the question?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: You'll see 'em, Sir, anon.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Wilt please your Grace?
sp.stage: Gives papers to the King (Cousen) and Hornet.
sp.l: And you Sir Giles, the subject of the Masque.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What's here, the three Goddesses
Contention for the golden ball?

div.stage: Enter Playfaire as Paris, dancing, with a Golden Ball in his hand.

sp.l: This is Paris; So.
These are the three Goddesses;
Juno, Pallas, Venus.

div.stage: The Goddesses dance, and court Paris for his Ball: Juno enters one like a King; Takes his Crowne and Scepter, offers it to Paris, he refuses.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: Juno doth wooe him with her State and Kingdomes.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: But he refuses, more foole he.

div.stage: To Pallas enter one like a Soldier armed, with a book in his hand; she presents the sword and book to Paris, but he rejects them.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: He is not for her service, though she offer
To make him Schollar and a Souldier:
A compleat man.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: No, no, that fairie must win the ball.
sp.stage: To Venus comes Cupid, leading in Hornet's Neece, richly drest.
sp.l: Ha? that's my Neece.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: Which, Sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: That whom Dame Venus and her Dandiprat
Are busie withall.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Why that's the Bride.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Bride, quotha?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: Married this morning; 'Tis my daughter, sir.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Nay, if she be my Neece, I am sure she was not
Married this morning.

div.stage: Paris receives the Neece, and gives Venus the Ball; Juno, Pallas, with their Masquers, Exeunt.
div.l: She's safe enough at home,
And has but halfe her wits, as I remember:
The devill cannot juggle her from my custody.
Ha, ha, I do dreame still.
div.stage: Cupid joins their hands and sings, exits with Playfaire and Neece.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: 'Tis time to breake off revels: How like you this, Sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A very fine dreame, ifaith.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I see you'd be a bed; You are not us'd
To these late houres.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: Lights for his Highnesse

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I humbly beg your license
I may returne to my owne lodging.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Well, sir, 'tis easily granted.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Lights for Sir Giles: One shall attend you home.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: Why do you laugh?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: At a conceit, at a conceit:
What did I eat last night, to make me dream thus?

div.stage: Enter Officers, with Hartwell in Startup’s clothes, followed by Countrey-man, and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You have done well?

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: Would you had done no worse.
These are his clothes, and you must give account
How you came by 'em, and produce him safe
Ere you acquit your selfe; We may suspect
You ha' kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Then I obey my destiny;
Justice I see pursues the guilty person:
Dispose me where you please.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: He does confesse.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What ere you be, you can but have my life
For his; all your revenge can reach no higher:
And to the law I yeeld my selfe.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: My hopes are colde
As his blood whom thou hast slaine: Thou hast
Been cruell in this act, to me and mine;
Whose fames in him are miserably wounded:
But looke for the reward.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I must expect it;
In the meane time I do not beg your mercy:
Life is a burden, I would faine be rid on't.
Does he weary me to carry it?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I'll acquaint my Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: Do so: To the next Justice; come away

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She's gone, she's gone, I shall run mad; My Neece,
Rob'd of three thousand pound in her escape,
I finde too late, I am awake and gull’d,
Nor know I whom to accuse for my tormentors;
Devils or men, but sure they were not men,
But very fiends fiend. An evil spirit generally; a demon, devil, or diabolical being; more fully fiend of hell. (OED n. 3) I revell'd with last night.
That I could meet the prince of devils that knighted me,
The Poets call him Pluto, god of riches;
I and my learned Councell would undo him
In Law, in very Law, which he should finde
Hotter ere I had done, than hell it selfe,
And call his place of torment, in three Termes,
But a refreshing to't: Yet let me see,
I have the portion still, though she be vanish'd,
That's better than my Neece, but if she marry,
I lose it all there; there's the vexation.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Save Mr. Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: 'Tis too late, away,
I do not love unnecessary complement.

sp.speaker: Cousen.
sp.l: This he?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Yes, I am he; am I not very fine?
What do you thinke this trim will cost me, ha?
Three thousand pounds, no more?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: The Broker wo'not
Lend halfe the money.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Will you, sir, be gone,
I ha' no money to lend now, it is not,
You know, in fashion, with rich clothes.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I came for other purpose, and with newes perhaps,
You would be willing to receive; You have
A Neece?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: No; such a creature was in my possession:
Do you know where she is?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Faith I imagine.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Ha, good sir? pray forwards:
You shall have money upon good security.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I thanke you, sir, for nothing; I do owe you
Too much already, on these tearmes.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: My Neece, as you were saying.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Were you knighted lately?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Is that talk'd abroad?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: No generall rumour; By a chance I came
Where such a thing was whisper'd only whisper'd;
Just as he was describ'd: In my opinion
Y'are very handsome, and do looke as like a reverend—

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Asse.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Why, you shall have it, sir.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: But touching my Neece, good sir,
That most ungracious giglet, giglet. A giddy, laughing, romping girl. (OED n. b)
That's run or stolne away, juggled last night
Out a my doores.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Did not she leap the casement? casement.A vertically hinged frame containing glass, forming (part of) a window. Hence (more generally): a window. (OED n. 2a)

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Do not increase my agony; you came—

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: With civill meaning to discover how
You may be abus'd.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What money do you want, sir?
Your owne bond shall suffice.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I ha sworne never
To write my name or marke; But I can tell—

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Where I may finde this girle.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: More I can do, if need require;
Tis in my power to give
Her back to your possession, and I am willing.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: An honest man.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: On reasonable conditions, and such
As shall not trench on borrowing money.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Honester yet.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: For you shall give it freely and get by't;
For you must understand if I do this,
I shall betray a friend of mine, that has
Put me in trust, one that intends to marry her,
(For truth to tell, they are not yet contracted)
To marry her, d'ee marke? and yet e're morning
Three thousand pounds upon her, Is't not so much?

div.l: One that has lent me sums too without parchment. parchment.Animal skin dressed and prepared for writing, painting, bookbinding, etc. (OED n. 1)
Or foolish circumstance, to be repaid;
Which you were never yet so much a Christian,
As to be guilt of, in your Usurers gallon

Of conscience melting Sacke;Lambert demands a bigger sum for returning the Neece, one of his arguments being that Hornet is a Jew and the individual who kidnapped the Neece is a Christian. This deserves something,
But cause some expedition is required;
You have a Bond of mine.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: For fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I had but forty, and your Scrivenor paid,
With whom, perhaps, your worship too divided;
If you remember, there were precious dinners,
Ere I could count my Chickens altogether,
Which was your thrift and my expence; You shall
First cancell that Bond, nay this wo'not dot,
And give, d'ee marke, give me a hundred pieces,
Perhaps I'll drinke your health: This shall retrive
Your Neece, and give her into your hands,
Though for my treachery, I be sung in ballads,
And have the towne curse if ever I marry.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: 'Tis too much for no more labour, sir.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: If I consider,
Three hundred will not bring me to't agen;
Thus faire I'll deale with you; I'le not touch your money
Till I ha' don't, but then I will be sure:
Fetch, fetch the businesse.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: The Bond is ready.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I will have ready money too: You have
Bags of all sizes and denominations.
I, these things promise well; now I'll attend you.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Do this fear for me, and 'tis all thine owne.

div.stage: A Room in Justice Clement's House.
Enter Justice Clement, Playfaire and Neece.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Now we may wish you say, the Priest has tied
That knot no subtity nor malice can
Dissolve; And repent not I have been
An actor in your Comedy, though I should not

div.l: Be tempted easily to such another
Engagement; For your sake I have dispenc'd with
My person and my place.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: You alwayes were
My loving Uncle.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Sir, you have, in this,
Deserv'd our lives and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: It was good mirth
To heare him confident all our device
Was but a dreame.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: He is awake by this time;
Should your Cousen faile, we'll have another way
To invite him; And if honesty prevaile not,
Force him till he consent.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Some offenders are brought to be examin'd.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Nephew, withdraw, and you, faire Bride; These troubles
Are incident to my place, I'll soon dispatch 'em.
How now my Masters? Mr. Hartwell? ha!

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Looke on me; Sir, as a delinquent; These
Are able to accuse me.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: What offence?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Nothing, but for killing of a man.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: What proofe?

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: He has confest it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Mistresse Bellamy,
You are come in a sad time: Here's Mr. Hartwell
Accus'd for killing.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Tis not possible.
Good sir beleeve it not.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: He does confesse.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I am not worth your pity, gentle lady
In vaine I should extenuate my fact,

div.l: To have the troubles of examinations;
Here I confesse agen, my hand is guilty
Of killing him whose feeble arme durst not
Lift up a weapon to defend himselfe.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: That was not manly.†manly. Used not as strong or masculine, but rather as humane, charitable; generous. Obsolete. (OED adj. c4).

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I but slew a coward
Startup, and could I call his life agen,
As soone I should destroy it; you perhaps
Know not my provocation: He was
My Rivall, sir, pardon me: Mistris Bellamy,
To whom I only seemed a Proselyte proselyte.A person who has changed from one opinion, religion, party, etc., to another; a convert. (OED n. 2)
In love, I had no heart to give from her:
And in my study to decline your anger;
I fell upon her scorne, which in few minutes,
Engaged me to this Fate; Nor am I troubled
That I must die, when she upon whose faith
I durst have laid the hopes of my eternity,
Hath violated all the trust of woman.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: Wilt please you, sir—

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Forbear a little.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Tell me, most unkinde, if thou didst love
At all? How couldst thou thinke I should be such
A desperate Atheist, that thou so soone,
And with a strange Apostacy apostacy.Abandonment or renunciation of one's religious faith or moral allegiance. (OED n. 1a) should'st revenge it?
These swelling drops which in thy innocence
Might ha' prevail'd to ha' restor'd the dead,
Heaven now doth looke on, and despise: And though
Thou shed moist tribute on this Tombe, 't shall slide,
Neglected o're the Marble, and be lost,
As if the stone had sense to punish thy
Disdaine of me: I can behold that weeping,
And not be moved to wish I were not guilty
Of killing him whose love had been thy triumph;
And I dare boldly, still in the contempt
Of what I am to suffer, and the justice
Of my owne truth, challenge thy soule to answer

div.l: In what I was beneath that gaudy gaudy.Excessively or glaringly showy, tastelessly fine or colourful. (OED adj.2. 3a) foole,
Excepting that he had more earth than I
To helpe his scale, which yet he may be indebt for
To his fathers sins: Alive, he could not merit
One cold disdaine from thee; And dead, how comes it
He should be worth thy teares? But let thy eyes
Chide this unruly sorrow; dresse thy cheekes
With their fresh blood again, and let thy face
Open a book of smiles, in the assurance
I have not long to live; When I have numbred
A few sad minutes, thou shalt be reveng'd,
And I shall never trouble thee: If this
Be not enough, extend thy malice further;
And if thou find'st one man that lov'd me living,
Will honour this cold body with a grave,
Be cruell, and corrupt his charity.
So fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Yet you must stay and heare me:
He sha'not suffer, if my friends or state
Can purchase him a pardon: Where's the body
Of him that's slaine?

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: We know not; But you heare
His free confession of the fact.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: This may
Proceed from discontents; Life to some men
Is but their torment in whose paine they will,
As on the Wracke, confesse what never
Was in their thought.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Speak it agen, and I
Dare promise thee to live.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: My heart was ever
Constant, my mothers love was but thy triall,
As mine a seeming change in thy disguise,
Which was not able to secure thee from me
The words were, I would choose my husband here
But what will this availe us?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Mr. Justice, I here discharge you.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: My joyes obeyes
No limits; I accus'd my selfe unjustly,
The fool's alive.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: Startup, Where?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I know not that,
My servant's with him, but if he ha' plaid
The hang-man,Hartwell means he does not know if Close has taken justice into his own hands and killed the Countrey-man. starv'd or smother'd him in a ditch,
I ha' made faire worke

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: This were a welcome truth.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, the Constable.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I had rather it had been my Kinsman and the Usurer;
But wait and give me knowledge when they come.

div.stage: Enter Constable, Startup, Close and Officers.

sp.speaker: Constable
