sp.l: Where's Mr. Justice?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: It is he and Close;
Then I am secure, your pardon, and thy love.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You have it freely, and a mother’s prayers
For both your happinesse.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Please your worship, these
We took last night i'th'fields suspiciously,
And by my owne authority I condemn'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Shall we be hang'd, Close, we are condemn'd already.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: This is the Gentleman was kill'd.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet sir, no;
Not kill'd out right, but I was almost starv'd
With cold: These Gentlewoman know me,
And I should know that Hose and Doublet too;

Those garments which you weare, I have oft seen, sweet sir.Like some of the lines spoken by the servants in Act I, Scene I, the last line of Startup's speech comes from Thomas Kyd's The Spanish Tragedy, and are said by Hieronimo, which explains Close's response.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Well saidJeronimo.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I was faine to borrow
These of a prisoner that lies in, upon
My Diamond Ring.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: You are discharg'd.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: And we too?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Yes, and joy in every bosome.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Close, you must know this your Mistresse: Sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: 'Tis enough for you to know her, sir,
And me to acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: Do you know me, sir?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Hum; yes, who brought you to town? And your daugh-
ter too, sweet sir?

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: And you shall right her.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Is she growne crooked? I knew her too well.
Peace, not a word more, I know your meaning,
Do not discredite me, sweet sir, and we'll steale downe
And marry her ere any be aware on't;
I wo'not stay to shift me, take no leave;
The jest will be when I am in the Countrey,
How like an asse he'll look in my apparrell.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, Mr. Playfaire’s Cousen and the other Gallant.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I must intreat your patience a little,
You'll meet with friends in the next roome.

div.stage: Exeunt Hartwell, Bellamy, Frances and Close.
Enter Cousen, and Hornet in his court dress.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Excuse my boldnesse, sir, this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Mr. Hornet, you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Good sir no ceremony; We are come
'Bout businesse: I have lost my Neece, and would
Know where she is.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: D'ee take me for a Wizzard?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Sir, our desires are modest; That you would
Be witnesse to a bargaine, and receive
Some trifles, sir, in trust to be deliver'd
To me, If I restore his Kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Not else; On that condition I deposite
These hundred pieces, and a bond, if he
Deliver me my Neece, they are his fraught,

div.l: If not, they call me owner.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Pardon, sir,
That I presume to bring this trouble to you.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: 'Tis none at all.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: You sha'not long expect: So rest you merry.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: How fare you, sir?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: As you see, falne away an inch since morning,
But this will physicke †physick.A healthy practice or habit, meaning “this will cure me”. Obsolete. (OED n. 2a) me; If I possesse

This harlotry †harlotry.Coarse or indecent language or behaviour; crude jesting; ribaldry; obscenity. Also in weaker sense: frivolous entertainment or behaviour, buffoonery. Obsolete. (OED, n. 1)agen, I'll make her sure:
Trust not a woman, they have found the herbe
To open locks; not brazen Towers can hold'em.
Or if they get not loose, they have the vertue
Of Loadstones; Shut up in a box, they'll draw
Customers to them; Nay, being dead and buried,
There is a suspicion they will breake the grave,
Which puts so many husbands to the charge
Of heavy stones to keep their bad wires under.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: You are moved?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Oh Mr. Justice you are honest,
I ha'been abus'd, so miserably cheated,
I am asham'd to thinke on't,
Stay, what, musicke?
Ha, 'tis my Neece; the very same.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: There, sir, you have her, and I must ha' these.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Take'em: But you shall go with me; have I found you?

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: How Unckle? a reveller? you'll lead me a Corranto.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You shall dance homewards.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: What make you so familiar with my wife?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: How, wife? is she married?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: 'Tis upon record,
I'll bring a Parson that shall take his oath on’t

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Give me my bond and money, Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Where? where?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Here, here, but not to be recovered

div.l: By law: I have a judgement, sir, against you.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You have conspired to rob, cheat, and undo me;
I'll have you all Star-chamber'd

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Sir, be calme, and hear us.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I'll hear nothing.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Yes, you shall;
It will be necessary, I am bold,
Presuming on her favour, to demand
A parcell of three thousand pound, the sum
belongs to me, by vertue of a marriage
And I must have it.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Tell me of a marriage?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I saw the Priest conjoyne'em †conjoyn. Unite in marriage. Obsolete. (OED. v. 1c) :
He will deserve your love.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Perhaps you may continue
A thousand, or two thousand, for six moneths,
Upon security.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Persecution.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Faith sir consider,
It is more safe to see her thus bestowed,
Than trust a jury; If the Doctor had
Given her too much Opium, or purg'd
Her soule away, things might go worse; But I
Keep counsell.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Ha'ye mortified me yet?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: For your owne sake, and as you are true Knight.

div.stage: Re-enter Mistresse Bellamy, Hartwell, Frances, and Close.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Now, ha ye done? The widdow;
Not a word more, take her, I'll pay you sir,
Three thousand pounds to morrow: Noble widdow
You were in the first list to be invited;
My Neece I told you of, is married to
This worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You looke like a Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: 'Tis in your power to make it good; What say you,
Shall we have issue? Now the word of comfort.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I will never marry.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You are resolv'd why, so: Come hither Nephew,
Shalt be my heire, I love thee for thy wit;
But charme thy friends, they do not laugh at me:
I'll be a Knight too, if I live, and build
An Hospitall for twenty more o'th' Order,
Which I'll reduce my selfe out of the Suburbs;
It is a shame such men should lose their spurs
In women’s Petticoats, and turne Squires agen
To Whores, or Parasites to Noble men,
For want of fit provision.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: An excellent foundation.
But where's Startup?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Sunke, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Never conjure for him; we are ingratefull to
Our blisse: But wasting of these precious minutes,
Which are so many ages, till the Church
Hath made us perfect.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Is there any more
Worke for the Priest? Then give you joy before hand,
And let us celebrate the day together.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I'me glad of your conversion; Ye are the first
Jew that in my remembrance has turn'd Christian.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Walke on to joyes.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: 'Twixt Love and Fortune, now the accounts are even:
A chaine of hearts, and the first linck in heaven.

div.stage:
Exeunt.
The 1667 edition of The Constant Maid includes the following epilogue:
Through many hazards, Love hath found a way,
For Friends to meet: good Omen to our Play.
If love hath brought you hither, Gentlemen,
Love will find out the way to come agen.
And we dare promise, if you rellish these,
Our Loves shall find out other ways to please.
T.B.
